name: Research
summary: Explorations

choices.name: Explore German research.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Using the articles and videos in this Choice, write down key learnings for research records. Then use the learnings for searches for an ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two or more ancestors.

content.text:
1. Basics: Get started researching German ancestors.

    ☆ FS Wiki—German Genealogy
    ☆ AC—German Research, Beginning—24:43 - 2013

  2. Learn about researching German ancestors in these articles.

    ☆ TH—Researching German Ancestors - 2018
    ☆ Basic Research Outline for German Genealogy

  3. Gathering Info: Use the Gathering Information article to help with German research.

    ☆ FS—Gathering Information

  4. Town of Origin: Learn about finding the German town of origin for your ancestor.

    ☆ PR—Finding German Immigrant Town of Origin, Part 1: Record Types
    ☆ PR—Finding German Immigrant Town of Origin, Part 2 : Advanced Strategies

  5. Learn more about finding the town of birth in this video.

    ☆ AAC—Finding the Town of Birth for Your German Ancestor—5:18

  6. Get tips for finding your German immigrant ancestor's hometown, in this blog post on the ☆Genealogy Roots Blog site.
  7. Tips: Watch this video for tips on finding German ancestors.

    ☆ FS—Finding German Ancestors: Tips from James Beidler - 2017



  8. Learn to avoid common problems in German research.

    ☆ AAC—Some Pitfalls in Germanic Research—2:33

Records
  1. Record FInder: Use the Germany Record Finder to understand record types for research.

    ☆ FS—Wiki: Germany Record Finder

  2. Record Types: Learn about different types of German source records.

    ☆ PR—German Original Sources

  3. Ancestry: Learn how to find German records for research in these Ancestry articles.

    ☆ AC—Researching German Records
    ☆ AC—Finding Your German Ancestors - 2016

content.text:
1. Terms: Study common German genealogy terms in these articles.

    ☆ TH—Genealogy Word List
    ☆ FS—Genealogy Word List - 2019  
    • Language Aids
    • Numbers
    • Dates and Time
  2. Surnames: Learn about German surname origins in these articles.

    ☆ TH—What Does Your German Last Name Mean? - 2019
    ☆ FS—Germany Names  
    • Surnames
    • Given Names
    • Names in Foreign Languages
    • Variations on Given Names
  3. Learn about the history of German surnames.

    ☆ What Your German Surname Says About Your Ancestors—8:31 - 2019



  4. Learn about surname variations in records.

    ☆ RT—Schmidt, Schmitt, or Schmit: German Surname Variations—21:26 - 2022



  5. Find German surnames by location in the Genealogy.net site.
  6. Explore ☆surname distribution (a map where certain surnames are prevalent) in Germany.
  7. Search for ☆German surnames in a number of databases.
  8. Spelling, Names, and Places: Learn about spelling variations in German names.

    ☆ FS—Spelling Variations in German Given and Place Names—57:42 - 2017

  9. Learn how to decipher German names and places.

    ☆ BYU—Deciphering Names of German People and Places—49:55 - 2022

choices.name: Use effective research methods for your German ancestors.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Using the articles and videos in this Choice, write down key learnings for research resources. Then use the learnings for searches for an ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two or more ancestors.

content.text:
1. Sites: Explore online databases and sites for German research.

    ☆ TH—German Genealogy Online

  2. Learn about the Compgen website for research.

    ☆ FTM—Compgen.de Tour—2:36 - 2018



  3. Resources: Watch this BYU Webinar to learn more about available online resources for German research.

    ☆ BYU—German Online Resources—40:59 - 2016



  4. Explore the FreeGermanAncestry site for a variety of research resources.
  5. Eastern Germany: Learn strategies for research in the eastern provinces of Germany.

    ☆ Strategies and Sources for Eastern Provinces—56:14
    ☆ RT—Searching For Your Elusive Prussian Ancestors: A Case Study—10:35 - 2022



  6. Correspondence: Use this guide for corresponding with German organizations about genealogy resources.

    ☆ FS—German Letter Writing Guide

Search
  1. Sites: Explore the Compgen.de website for help with researching German ancestors.
  2. Explore the FEEFHS website (Foundation for Eastern European Family History Studies) for German research resources.
  3. Explore the ☆Forebears.io site for research records.
  4. Search for ancestor records on the Meta Genealogy site.

choices.name: Learn how to interpret old German handwriting and scripts.

content.text:
1. Skills: Learn more about German vocabulary and handwriting in this video.

    ☆ AAC—Basic German Vocabulary and Handwriting—3:33

  2. Examples: See examples of how to read German records.

    ☆ AC—Reading German Documents

  3. Learn how to read the popular Suetterlin script with examples and tutorials.
  4. Learn how to read Old German script Suetterlin script with samples and downloadable fonts.
  5. Video Series: Watch the German Paleography Seminar, a series of videos from FamilySearch.

    ☆ FS—German Paleography Series - 2019

  6. Tutorial: Explore the BYU German Script Tutorial.

Search

  3. Explore the Archives section of the German Websites Wiki page for additional information.
  4. Explore the ☆Books We Own site for books that can be checked out or researched for you by others.

content.text:
1. Introduction: Learn about Germany church records in this FamilySearch Wiki article.

    ☆ FS—Wiki: Germany Church Records   
    • Church Records
    • Information Recorded in Church Records
    • Locating the Records
    • Reading the Records

  2. Learn about German church records on FamilySearch.

    ☆ German Church Records on FamilySearch—61:06 - 2019


    ☆ FS—German Church Records and How to Use them on FamilySearch - 2019

  3. Records: Watch this video for tips on finding and using German church records.

    ☆ AAC—Finding and Using German Church Records—7:10

  4. Explore the Churches section of the German Research Websites page for additional information.
  5. Learn about the research clues you can get from tracing godparents.

    ☆ PR—Godparents Provide Clues in German Research

  6. Archion.de: Learn about the Archion.de website and its Protestant church record resources.

    ☆ FS—Archion—6:48 (German) - 2018
    ☆ RT—Finding Your German Protestant Ancestors With Archion—16:43 - 2022


  7. Pomerania: Learn how to find church and civil records in the province of Pomerania.

    ☆ FS—Searching for Pomerania (Pommern), Germany Church and Civil Records Using Pommerscher Greif—5:19

Parishes
  1. Learn how to find German parish records.

    ☆ FS—Map Guide to German Parish Registers, Part 1 - 2016
    ☆ FS—Map Guide to German Parish Registers, Part 2 - 2016

  2. Explore Protestant parish registers on the EZA site. For tips on getting started with parish research, click here.
  3. Church & Town: Learn about connections between German church and town records.

    ☆ FS—German Church Records and Beyond—62:34 - 2017
    ☆ German Ortsfamilienbücher (town family books)

Jewish
  1. Learn the basics of German Jewish research in these articles.

    ☆ PR—German Jewish Research – Part 1
    ☆ PR—German Jewish Research – Part 2

  2. Explore Jewish genealogy in Germany in this guide from the ☆Center for Jewish History site.
  3. Explore the ☆Jewish Genealogy Encyclopedia for Jewish resources in Germany.
  4. Explore the ☆JewishGen Germany database.

content.text:
1. FamilySearch: Learn about Germany emigration and immigration in this FamilySearch Wiki article.

    ☆ FS—Wiki: Germany Emigration and Immigration  
    • History
    • Finding the Immigrant's Town of Origin
    • Emigration from Germany
    • Passports
    • United States

  2. Explore the Emigration and Immigration section of the FamilySearch German Websites page for additional information.
  3. Wikipedia: Learn about immigration history and demographics in this Wikipedia article.

    ☆ Wikipedia: German Americans

  4. Overview: Here's an overview of German emigration history and records. See more information in the links on the right side of the linked page.

    ☆ European Emigration: Germany

  5. Germans to America: Learn about Germans coming to America in this article and video.

    ☆ TH—Germans to America
    ☆ AAC—German Migration to the United States—5:01

  6. Germans in Russia: Learn about Germans emigrating to Russian and then to America.

    ☆ FS—Germans from Russia: An Overview—30:28 - 2019
    ☆ FS—Germans from Russia: Locating the Town with Websites and Gazetteers—59:42 - 2019

  7. Germans to Russia: Explore the American Historical Society of Germans from Russia site to learn about German emigration to greater Russia, including Poland, Moldova, Romania, etc.

  8. Germans in Eastern Europe: Learn how to locate your German ancestors who may have migrated to Eastern Europe.

    ☆ Researching the "Germans Outside Germany" in Eastern Europe

  9. Palatine Emigration: Learn about the Palatines who emigrated to America and the British Isles in the 1700s.

    ☆ OT—Palatine German Immigration & Genealogy

Records
  1. Learn about record types that can help you trace immigration.

    ☆ FS—Finding German Places of Origin—56:42 - 2017

  2. Church Records: Learn about German immigrants in American church records.

    ☆ LT—German Immigrants in American Church Records

  3. Passenger Lists: Learn about Hamburg passenger lists.

    ☆ FS—German Emigration Sources: Hamburg Passenger Lists—22:45 - 2018

choices.name: Explore German emigration resources.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Using the articles and videos in this Choice, write down key learnings for immigration records. Then use the learnings for searches for an ancestor.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two or more ancestors.

content.text:
1. Explore the Emigration from Southwest Germany website.
  2. Explore the German Immigrants Database website.
  3. Explore the Bremen Passenger List website.
  4. Explore the Hamburg Passenger Lists on the Genealogy.net site.
  5. Explore German and Swiss immigration to the U.S. and Canada in the Olive Tree Genealogy site.
  6. Explore the Germans to America online database.
  7. Explore the Immigrant Ancestors site from Brigham Young University.
  8. Explore the ☆Immigrant Ship site. Select a Volume, then choose Germany as the departure or arrival location.
  9. Explore the Immigrant Genealogical Society website.
  10. Explore the AGGSH emigrant website.

content.text:
1. Find links to German newspapers on the Wikipedia site.
  2. Search German newspapers in the ☆onlinenewspapers.com site.
  3. Search German historic newspapers in the ☆Oxford LibGuides site.
  4. Search German newspapers in the ☆ABYZ News Links site.

choices.name: There are a number of websites with valuable resources for German research.

content.text:
1. Explore links in the FamilySearch Wiki.
  2. Explore links in ☆Cyndi's List.
  3. Explore links in ☆Genealogylinks.net.
  4. Explore links in the ☆GermanRoots website.
  5. Explore links in the ☆Max Kade Institute website.

choices.name: Use QUIKLinks, Partners, and GenealogyInTime to quickly search the most common record collections for Germany.

content.text:
1. QUIKLinks are indicated by lightning-bolt icons in the Goals above.They point to collections with 50,000 or more records. When you click a QUIKLink icon, scroll down on the resulting page to see the QUIKLinks.
  2. In the Partners section (near the top of the page), explore additional record collections in FamilySearch, Ancestry, Findmypast and MyHeritage.
  3. Explore the FamilySearch page for German online record collections.
  4. Explore the Europe page of the GenealogyInTime website. Record collections are listed and described in order from newest to oldest additions, including FamilySearch, Ancestry, and many other sources.

name: Get Help
section_name: Get help with your Germany research.

choices.name: Use Facebook pages to get answers to your questions.

content.text:
1. Visit the ☆German Genealogy Facebook page.
  2. Visit the ☆German Genealogist Facebook page.
  3. Visit the ☆Central Europe Genealogy Research Community on Facebook.
  4. See the Genealogy on Facebook list of Facebook groups dedicated to helping with research for Germany.

choices.name: Join a mailing list, community, or message board for Germany research.

content.text:
1. Explore the ☆FamilySearch community for German research.
  2. Explore the ☆Germany research mailing lists on Cyndi's List.
  3. Use the ☆Ancestry message boards to read or post questions about Germany research.
  4. Explore Germany research questions in the ☆Genealogy Stack Exchange.

choices.name: Learn about Germany genealogy societies.

content.text:
1. Learn about Germany genealogy societies in this FamilySearch Wiki article.

    ☆ FS—Wiki: Germany Societies

  2. Explore the ☆Germanic Genealogy Society site.

  3. Explore the ☆AGFHS (Anglo-German Family History Society site.

  4. Explore ☆Germany genealogy society sites on Cyndi's List.

  5. Get help at a family history center in Germany.
